content:
Suggest changing "English" to "American English" or "short scale English" in the task description, so we don't have to guess whether "one billion" is 10^9 or 10^12.

Especially since you chose to list no vocabulary in the task description!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I had fun trying to handle -2^64  in C++ ^^.

Hello Allis,

This looks fun and would like to try it in Java.

But there is an issue when checking some tests with the default code.

Test NÂ°7
Exception in thread "main" java.util.InputMismatchException: For input string: "100000000000"
(same by modifying to nextLong() the x value.
"10000000000000000000"

It can not be parsed as an Integer or as long. Xi does not fit ^^

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice string manipulation puzzle !
It seems easy enough, and still can be challenging for beginners.
I didn't see any easy problem that looks like this one yet on CG.
And I would like solving it in some languages.
So ... Approved !

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice easy (but not obvious) puzzle

I think it is perfect for an easy puzzle...and it is a bit too much, so that it would scare people away from COC.

Just need to specify clearly the "negative" part on the description.

And it seems that there is no write/print... sentence on the auto-generated code

Otherwise, ready for approval :-))

That "hyphens where appropriate" is going to need a bit more detail.

Edit: also those "negative" in the testcases aren't hinted or specified by the statement.

Hey, folks. I finally figured out how to be terse in problem statements! In fact, given that it's so short, you might think this more suitable to a Clash problem, but getting it just right is probably a little too tricky to be done in 15 minutes, so I erred on the side of caution.
Is there a succinct way to refer to the numbers that require hyphenation in English? "Double-digit" doesn't quite get there.

Appreciate your approval. :)

I thought the potential for negatives was a nice little "surprise", and since the puzzle isn't time-sensitive, I went ahead and emphasized the lower bound in the constraints section as a happy middle ground.

Added a print statement to the template and clarified the definition of the inputs a bit. Should be ready to go.
and useless ... playing with strings is more fun and efficient
Well, I could agree for performance, which was not something I tried to optimize. I wanted to solve this puzzle with numbers instead of strings, I doubt that usefulness has anything to do here ^^.

Oh, shoot. I specifically chose that limit so that it would *just* be manageable in languages without native bignum support, but I forgot that signed integers have to steal one of the bits for the sign.

Sorry about that! Glad you still managed to get it solved.

I understand your point on the "negative" it adds a little surprise easy to solve.

And for me the hyphen thing is clear.

:-)
By the way... why the title?
They're the names of two random English cardinals. ðŸ˜…
